titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the United Women Firefighters Records and Photographs WAG.057
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Laurie B. Green, 1987, and Jennifer Steenshorne, 2006

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from United Women Firefighters Wag 57 replacement.doc

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-08-28T17:06-0400

change.item: Finding aid written by Laurie B. Green, 1987, and Jennifer Steenshorne, 2006, updated to include materials reincorporated from the United Women Firefighters Photographs (NP 140) by Hanan Ohayon

did.unittitle: United Women Firefighters Records and Photographs

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

physdesc.extent: in 14 record cartons, 2 manuscript boxes and one folder.

did.abstract: The United Women Firefighters (UWF) was founded in 1982 as a support organization for women firefighters in the New York City Fire Department. The New York City Fire Department began accepting applications from women for the position of firefighter in 1977, but did not hire any women until after Brenda Berkman successfully sued the City of New York on behalf of herself and other women who had passed the written examination, questioning the validity of the physical exam. The UWF was founded to deal with the occupational and sexual discrimination and the sexual harassment women firefighters faced. These records cover Brenda Berkman's career, legal cases (Brenda Berkman et al. v. City of New York et al.; Brenda Berkman et al. v. City of New York et al., Appeal; and Brenda Berkman v. City of New York, Carlos Rivera, & Selig Ginsberg), and the founding and development of the United Women Firefighters of New York City and the related national support group, Women in Fire Service (WFS, alternately known as Women in Fire Suppression). The collection contains scrapbook material, personal correspondence, legal documents, organizational files, subject files, clippings, photographs, videos and memorabilia.

custodhist.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
custodhist.p: The original donation of material to the Wagner Labor Archives was made by Brenda Berkman and the United Women Firefighters in 1987. A subsequent donation of four boxes was made by Brenda Berkman in 2002, and additional materials were added by Berkman in 2005 and 2011.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The New York City Fire Department (NYCFD, also known as the FDNY by the department) began accepting applications from women for the position of firefighter in 1977, but did not hire any women until after Brenda Berkman successfully sued the City of New York on behalf of herself and other women who had passed the written examination. Berkman, a law student at New York University at the time of her application, sued the City under the 1964 Civil Rights Act, questioning the validity of the physical exam. In 1982, Judge Charles Sifton ruled that the City had indeed discriminated against women through its physical exam, known as the 3040 exam, which included tests that were biased against women and unrelated to a firefighter's future performance on the job. The suit and Sifton's ruling sparked intense controversy in the Fire Department and the media. Litigation related to this original ruling continued until 1988.

The United Women Firefighters (UWF) was founded in 1982 by the first group of New York City women firefighters, in order to deal with the occupational and sexual discrimination, and the sexual harassment, encountered in the Department. Modeled on groups like the Vulcan Society (representing African-American firefighters), the UWF assists women firefighters who have encountered a wide range of problems on the job, from ill-fitting equipment to unjust probation and sexual assault. They have lobbied for training for all officers and firefighters on issues related to women on the job. Representatives of the organization have developed ties with other women firefighters' organizations, including the national coalition, Women in Fire Service. The United Women Firefighters publishes a monthly newsletter, the Voice Alarm.

Brenda Berkman was born in 1951, and became interested in firefighting as a young girl. When she accepted the Susan B. Anthony Award from the National Organization of Women in 1984, she declared that she had become a feminist at age seven, when she was not allowed to play in boys-only Little League. She earned her B.A. from St. Olaf College in Minnesota, an M.A. in History at Indiana University, a J.D. from New York University Law School, and an M.S. in Fire Protection Management from the City University of New York. At the time of her application to the New York Fire Department she was a law student at New York University.

Berkman is a founding member and former president of the United Women Firefighters (1982-1986) and served as trustee of the Women in Fire Service (1983-1992). She taught at the FDNY fire academy and the United States National Fire Academy. Her many awards and honors include the Susan B. Anthony award from the National Organization for Women (1984), a Revson Fellowship on the Future of the City of New York from Columbia University (1987-1988), the distinguished alumni award from St. Olaf College, and the National Organization for Women's Women of Courage Award (2002). For her support of labor history and labor archives, she was honored by the New York Labor History Association in 2005.

Berkman was a featured participant in the PBS program, "Sex, Power, and the Workplace" (1992) and was the subject of the Off-Broadway play, "Firework" (2002). Her story and that of her fellow women firefighters is the focus of the documentary, "Taking the Heat: The First Women Firefighters of New York City" (2006). She was promoted to Captain in 2002, only the third woman to achieve that rank.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of scrapbook material, personal correspondence, legal documents, organizational files, subject files, clippings, memorabilia, photographs and videos from circa 1977 to 2011. The materials document the life and career of Brenda Berkman, the successful legal actions Berkman brought against the City of New York and the New York City Fire Department (Berkman v. the City of New York; Berkman v. NYCFD) between 1977 and 1993, and the unsuccessful appeal by the City of New York to Judge Charles Sifton's 1982 ruling that the City had discriminated against women through its physical exam. The collection also documents the founding and operation of the United Women's Firefighters, and the related national support group, Women in Fire Service.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Copyright is held by Brenda Berkman and the United Women Firefighters.

Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the:
Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012
Phone: (212) 998-2630
Fax: (212) 995-4225
E-mail: tamiment.wagner@library.nyu.edu

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p:
Published citations should take the following form:
Identification of item, date; United Women Firefighters Records and Photographs; WAG 057; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The records are arranged in five series, two of which have been further arranged in subseries. The contents of each series or subseries are arranged alphabetically, and chronologically within subject when appropriate, with the exception of Series V which consists of unprocesssed materials. The series and subseries arrangement of the records is as follows:

Series I, Brenda Berkman Papers, 1977-2005
Series II, Legal Files, 1979-1993
Subseries A: Brenda Berkman et al. v. City of New York et al. (Case No. 79, C 1813), Class Action Suit, Legal Documents, 1979-1986
Subseries B: Brenda Berkman et al. v. City of New York et al. (Case No. 79, C 1813), Class Action Suit, Subject Files, 1979-1990
Subseries C: Brenda Berkman et al. v. City of New York et al. (Case no. 82-7654), Appeal, 1982
Subseries D: Brenda Berkman v. New York City Fire Department, Carlos Rivera, and Selig Ginsberg, (Case no. E-92-0575), 1987-1993
Series III, Organizational Files, 1977-2002
Subseries A: United Women Firefighters, 1977-2002
Subseries B: Women in Fire Suppression/Fire Service, 1983-1999
Series IV, Photographs and Memorabilia, circa 1980-1999
Series V, Unprocessed Materials, 1957-2011

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Photographs and memorabilia were separated from this collection during processing and were established as a separate collection, the United Women Firefighters Photographs (NP 140). In 2013, the photograph and memorabilia collection was reincorporated into the United Women Firefighters Records (WAG 057).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series includes biographical material on Brenda Berkman, clippings related to her career, correspondence from her legal practice, and materials from her scrapbooks, primarily dealing with the case, Berkman v. City of New York.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The series consists of legal documents and subject files from court cases brought by Brenda Berkman against the City of New York and the New York City Fire Department between 1977 and 1993, and from an unsuccessful appeal by the City of New York to Judge Charles Sifton's 1982 ruling that the City had discriminated against women through its physical exam. Includes materials from the following cases: Brenda Berkman et al. v. City of New York et al. (Case No. 79, C 1813), Class Action Suit (Berkman v. City of New York), 1977-1990; Brenda Berkman et al. v. City of New York et al. (Case no. 82-7654), Appeal, 1982 (Berkman v. City of New York, Appeal); and Brenda Berkman v. New York City Fire Department, Carlos Rivera, and Selig Ginsberg (Case no. E-92-0575), 1991-1993 (Berkman v. NYCFD).

did.unittitle: Subseries A: Brenda Berkman et al. v. City of New York et al. (Case No. 79, C 1813), Class Action Suit, Legal Documents, 1979-1986

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged chronologically and by suit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Subseries is comprised of legal documents (defendants' papers, exhibits, plaintiff's papers, and testimony), relating to the court case Berkman v. City of New York. This material covers not only the original case, but seven subsequent suits related to the dismissal and reinstatement with back-pay of firefighters Brenda Berkman and Zaida Gonzalez in 1983, the harassment cases of firefighters Katrina Cannon and Ella McNair, and the revised physical exam, 1162.

This material covers not only the original case, but seven subsequent suits related to the dismissal and reinstatement with back-pay of firefighters Brenda Berkman and Zaida Gonzalez in 1983, the harassment cases of firefighters Katrina Cannon and Ella McNair, and the revised physical exam, 1162.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Subseries consists of subject files, and includes correspondence, clippings, court papers, medical records, and press conference materials concerning Berkman's 1992 sexual harassment suit (Berkman v. NYCFD) against the New York City Fire Department, Fire Commissioner Carlos Rivera, and departmental physician, Dr. Selig Ginsberg.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series consists of organizational files of the United Women Firefighters (UFW) from 1977-2002, and of Women in Fire Service (WFS), alternately known as Women in Fire Suppression, from 1983-1995.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Subseries includes materials related to the founding and operation of the UWF, such as clippings, correspondence, organizational materials, press conferences, the physical exam, membership, the FDNY's Special Advisory Committee on Women, and materials related to the training course at John Jay College of Criminal Justice-CUNY.

Subseries B: Women in Fire Suppression/Fire Service, 1983-1999

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The WFS is a national organization of women in firefighting, founded in 1982 by firefighters Terese Floren and Linda Willing. Brenda Berkman served as a trustee of the WFS from 1983 to 1992. The WFS publishes a newsletter, Firework. The series includes correspondence, materials related to the regional and national conferences on women in firefighting sponsored by the WFS, transcriptions of interviews with Brenda Berkman from a 1987-1988 oral history project, membership, and organizational materials.

did.unittitle: Conferences, Fourth National, San Diego, CA
Oral History Project: Interviews with Brenda Berkman (2) and Terese Floren
Publications, Handbook on Women in Fire Fighting

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Series consists of approximately one hundred black-and-white and color prints of various sizes, nineteen color slides, a small amount of negatives, and one black-and-white contact sheet, with portraits, event and documentary photographs from circa 1980 to 1999. Also includes a small amount of artifacts and memorabilia from Brenda Berkman's career as a firefighter including badges, membership cards, a UWF pin, FDNY calendars, and ephemera related to Berkman's termination in 1983.

Photographs include a 5x7 black-and-white print and corresponding 4x5 negative of Berkman in FDNY uniform; black-and-white prints, and color prints and negatives, from a City Council Press Conference on July 19, 1992; 4x6 color prints from a Women's Action Coalition Demonstration against FDNY sexual harrassment on September 10, 1992; and 8x10 black-and-white prints including Brenda Berkman speaking at a press conference with city officials, of Women Tell the Truth: A Conference on Parity, Power and Sexual Harrassment on April 25th, 1992 at Hunter College, including Anita Hill and Gloria Steinem, and of Berkman and Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman. Two large color group portraits of women firefighters include the Fourth National Conference of Fire Service Women in San Diego in 1991.

Nineteen color slides, mostly from 1982, include images of the first women firefighters training for their physical exam in 1982, including at the Fire Academy on Randall's Island; candidate Katrina Cannon taking the oath of office in 1982 as a probationary firefighter, representing the first group; portraits of Brenda Berkman and attorney Robert King; as well as a group portrait, circa 1988, of the first women firefighters of New York City.
